Author: brlewis
Content: If friendfeed queries your SUP feed N times as frequently, the breakeven point for http requests is approximately N regular feeds, assuming those feeds aren't constantly updating.  In fact, the SUP feed is small, so it's not at all hard to break even on bandwidth, even with 1 or 2 feeds.

Author: dannyr
Title: I'm a .Net Developer and wants to learn another programming language
Content:
I'm a .Net guy and looking to find a job in a startup/Web 2.0 company.

There are some .Net jobs for startups but not as much as Php and Ruby.

I'm developing a new app and I want to use a new programming language.

Any suggestions on what I should use?

To be honest, I want a programming language to brighten my job prospects and future.

Author: blogimus
Content:
It is OS X only, not open source, and I haven't used it myself, but I've heard a lot of recommendations for OmniGraffle.

http://www.omnigroup.com/applications/omnigraffle/

I was in the market for just such a beast a couple of years back: open source, high quality, cross platform. I'm not sure it exists yet.

Author: jmtulloss
Content:
I've always felt that everybody should learn some assembly. It helps in understanding C, which in turn helps in understanding most of the other languages we work with.

That being said, to actually understand what was going on would take hours of carefully inspecting the code. That's why knowing assembly is like knowing latin.

Author: Goladus
Content:
From the Wikipedia Notability Guidlines page:

If it is likely that independent sources could be found for a topic, deletion due to lack of notability is inappropriate unless active effort has been made to find these sources. For articles of unclear notability, deletion should be a last resort.

That's why people "go nuts." Whoever nominated this for deletion was either lazy and stupid or just looking for some drama.

Author: scylla
Content: The advantage is equally huge for time & materials. $25/hr vs $75/hr. Do you think management anticipates that it will take three times as long?

Author: terpua
Title: Ask HN: DIY storage or not?
Content:
We have developed a generic syncing app (web, desktop, mobile) on top of cloud storage (S3 initially). We are moving to testing soon and can offer either a hosted version or let customers use their S3 account. Which offering would you advice we focus and why?

Our thoughts:

   1. Focusing on latter differentiates us
   2. Allows us to "plug" into future cloud storage (Goog, Msft, etc)
   3. However, not sure if market today is "too niche"
   4. Audience is individuals and businesses
Thanks in advance.

Author: blogimus
Content: I'd even say it is a hasty generalization.

Author: jmtulloss
Content: I think their answer to that was the short development cycles. If they're not the team you want, you'll see that in two weeks instead of 6 months.

Author: blogimus
Content:
Invite codes are a good way to limit access as you ramp up and also let you have a rough idea of which users are externally connected, even if it is not very accurate.

I'd say use as a marketing ploy is limited, unless one can successfully foster some kind of "gotta have" site before and during launch, and the vast majority of sites don't fit this bill.

Author: Bluem00
Title: Why use invite codes?
Content:
You've built a cool website and want to get some real, actual, users. In this situation, some companies create a mechanism by which only people that have invite codes can log in, and then these people are given a few invite codes for their friends. What is the reason to use invite codes in this manner as opposed to just allowing anyone to sign up?

Is it a marketing ploy, attempts to limit server load, something to make TechCrunch write about you?

Thanks!

Author: briansmith
Content:
Keep in mind that this is only helpful for sites that publish large numbers of feeds. For a site that has only one or two feeds (that is, the typical self-hosted weblog or company site), SUP will hurt more than it helps.

Basically, it is just a feed where each entry links to an updated feed-- a RSS-formatted sitemap (http://sitemap.org) where all the non-feed entries are removed.

Sixapart has had a similar interface for a while: http://updates.sixapart.com/
